key_points: The House voted to impeach President Donald Trump for a second time, making it the most bipartisan impeachment in history with 10 Republican representatives voting for it.
197 Republicans still voted against impeaching Trump.
This event is historic due to the high level of polarization and the usual party-line nature of past impeachments.
Previous impeachments (Andrew Johnson, Bill Clinton, and first Trump impeachment) displayed almost no cross-party support.
Rep. Liz Cheney and Rep. Tom Rice, among the Republicans who voted for impeachment, are not considered moderates by most objective observers.
Trump's job approval rating among Republicans has recently dropped but remains above 70%.
Two of the Republicans who voted for impeachment come from Washington state, known for its top-two primary system.
The impeachment attempt against President Richard Nixon in 1974 is the only historical parallel with considerable Republican support.
No Democrats voted against impeaching Trump, highlighting a record level of unity within the party.
Impeachment is only the first step, with the Senate's reaction to this vote being uncertain.
